cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Ormus" will leave Suez about December 27
R.M.S "Oruba" will leave Suez about January 9.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Port Said about December 30
R.M.S. “Ophir" will leave Port Said January 13

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Special reduced rates during Summer season.
Agents, Cairo: Thomas Cook & Son, Ltd. ; Alexandria : R. J. Moss & Co.
For all imformation apply to Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-6

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL TWIN-SCREW STEAMERS.
div.p: OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON.
S.S. Staffordshire 5,775 tons, will leave Suez about December 23.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.
S.S. Cheshire 7,182, will leave Port Said about December 19.
Fares from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0 ; London £17.0.0 ; Colombo £32.10.0 ; Rangood £37.10.0
Fitted with Refigerators, Electric Light, Electric Fans and all recent improvements.
SPECIAL REDUCED FARES DURING THE SUMMER SEASON. 12-931
Agents in Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. For all particulars apply to WM. STAPLEDON & SONS PORT SAID PORT TEWFIK (Suez).

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Shortest, calmest, most beautiful sea passage to Europe. Express steamers leave Alexandria 4 p.m. every Wednesday for Pireus. (Athens), Smyrne, Mitylene, Constantinople, in connection with Orient Express luxe train for Sofia, Belgrade, Budapest, Vienna, Paris, London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 5 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
SUDAN EXPRESS MAIL SERVICE.

KKHARTOUM in 3 days. Express steamers leave Suez Docks 5 p.m. every Wednesday for Port Sudan (and Suankin) in connection with Sudan Government Railways Express Luxe Service to Khartoum, arriving 8 p.m. Saturdays.
Steamers from Suez 5 p.m. every Monday evening for Jedda, calling one week at Tor, El-Wedj; Yambo, Jedda; and the following week at Tor, Yambo, Jedda, Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeida, Aden.
For frieght or passagee apply the Co.'s Agencies Alexandria, Port Said, Suez, Cairo; or for passages only to Thos. Cook & Soy, Hamburg- Amerika Linie, Reisse Burrati or other Tourist Agencies.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular fortnightly Service from HAMBURG; weekly from ANTWERP; every 4 weeks from Bordeaux direct to ALEXANDRIA for Rotterdam and Hamburg. Goods forwarded at through- rates from all German Railway Stations on direct Bills of Lading to ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO, SYRIA, ETC. Special facilities for conveyance of cotton, etc from Alexandria via Rotterdam and Hamburg to German manufacturing towns. For tarift and particulars apply to Adolphe Stross. Alexandria Agent- The following are expected at Alexandria: Dec 21 S.S "Hythnos", from Antwerp -Dec. 22 S.S "Pyrgos" from Hamburg - Dec 23 S.S. "Royal" from Hamburg.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Philae now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, December 16, to be followed by S.S. Monepthah.s.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars apply R. J MOSS & CO. ALEXANDRIA AGENTS
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO’s LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON and Algiers or LIVERPOOL direct.
(Electric Light.) SALOON (Amidships) FARE £12. (Latest improvements.)
S.S. AVA 7100 Tons bruthen, will leave Port Said about Dec. 7th for Hamburg, and Glasgow landing U.K. passengers Devonport.
S.S. MARTABAN 5600 Tons will leave Alexandria about December the 23rd, for London, Liverpool and Glasgow.
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 13 days thereafter.
The Saloon accommodation is amidships, and the vessels are fitted throughout with Electri Light, and have all the latest improvements.
For furthur information apply to the Company's Agents.
Apply WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: SUDAN DEVELOPMENT & EXPLORATION COMPANY, LIMITED
div.p: KHARTOUM: CAIRO Office, Sharia Kasr-el-Nil.

TRANSPORT DEPARTMENT. Six days White Nile Tourist Trip dep. Khartoum Tuesdays. Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at all Cairo Tourist Agents. - Special Steamers for private charter. - Trips arranged and transport of goods undertaken to all places on White and Blue Niles within navigation limits.

ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT. Shipyard for construction of sternwheel steamers, barges, stream, motor launches, etc. Contractors for supply and erection of all classes of machinery, buildings, irrigation pumps, etc.

Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum.-Moderate fares.
Specially Reduced Rates for residents of Egypt by Tourist Services during November and December. First sailing November 13th.
WEEKLY FREIGHT SERVICE FROM CAIRO TO ASSUAN AND HALFA.
Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at principal Railway Stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their tickets.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT; Lowest rates.
Best camp equipment in the country.

Branches in London, Liverpool, Manchester, Morocco, Tunis, East India, Madagascar, Australia, etc. Bills Collected. Deposit Accounts opened at sight & for fixed periods, Advances on securities, in current account. Letters of Credit and Telegraphic Transfers Issued. Foreign Exhange Bought and Sold. Stocks and Valuables received in safe custody. Purchase and Sale of Stock & Shares in Egypt and Abroad. Dividends Collected.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: CAPITAL FRANCS 250,000,000 ENTIEREMENT VERSES
Agences d’Egypte : ALEXANDRIE, LE CAIRE, PORT-SAID.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que : Avances sur titres fixes et en compte courant, Avances sur marchandises et consignations, Emission de traités et chèques, Emission de lettres de Crédit, Paiements par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France èt de l’étranger, Garde de titres Recouvrement d’effets sur l’Egypte et l'étranger ; le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds en compte de depôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe au taux de 3 o/o pour 1 an et au-delà. 31-12-906

div.head: BANK OF ATHENS, LIMITED.
div.p: Head Office : Athens — Capital 40,000.000 (Fully paid up). — Reserve 1,000,000.

Patras, Yolo, Syra, Calamata. The Bank undertakes all banking business in Egypt, Greece, etc. Interests on cash deposits,
3 0/0 per ann. at sight; 3 1/2 0/0 per ann. for 6 months; 4 0/0 per ann. for 12 months; 5 0/0 per ann. for 3 years and over. Savings
Bank Branch receives deposits at 3 1/2 0/0 per ann., from P.T. 80 to P.T. 20,000. 19-1-907

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: Capital: £3,000,000. RESERVE (Environ) : £1,500,000. MR. F. T. ROWLATT, Governor

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s’occupe de l’achat et de la vente d'effets sur l’Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-906

div.head: CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN
div.p: Capital 12,500,000 Francs entièrement verses. — Agence d’Alexandrie, 14, Rue Stamboul.

LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN fait toutes opérations de Banque, notamment: Escompte d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'etranger. Avance sur titres.—Garde de titres.—Depots de fonds a vue et à échéance fixe avec intérêts aux taux suivants: 2 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts de 6 mois, 3 0/0 pour dépôts d’un an, 3 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts au délà d’un an. — LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN reçoit des Marchandises en consignation pour la vente et fait des Avances sur Cotons, Grains et autres marchandises. — 2833781-3-908

div.p: CAIRO.
CAPITAL: Lstg. 600,000.

The Banque du Caire Ltd., undertakes all banking business such as : Advances on deeds and securites, discount, cheques delivered at very best rates of exchange on all the principal towns of the world, telegraphic transfers, purchase and sale of stock and shares in Egypt and abroad, letters of credit issued, safe custoday at a low charge, of titles, deeds and securities, current accounts opened. Receives money on deposit at sight at 3% per annum.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice Trieste. Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria Saturdays 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi Tuesdays 5 a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival at Venice Wednesday about 9.30 a.m. Passengers may proceed from Venice to Switzerland, Paris and London by the 2 p.m. and 11.5 p.m. – Expresses. Arrival at Trieste Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with the Train de Luxe proceeding the same evening to Vienna, Frankfort, Cologne, Brussel, Ostende and London. Arrival at London every Friday 5.12 p.m.
Special Train Service from Cairo Station to Alexandria Quay alongside steamer, Saturdays at 9.30 a.m.
Steamer leaves Alexandria every Thursday 4 p.m.

div.head: Hotel Beau-Rivage.
div.p: Ramleh – most charming Seaside Residence in Egypt
15 Minutes by Carriage or "Palais" tram from Sidi Gaber Station.
First Class Family Hotel with Every Modern Comfort. Unique Situation on the Beach.
Lovely Garden. Lawn Tennis. Large Terrace. Electric Light. Own springs. Perfect sanitary arrangements. Stables for horses and carriages.
Moderate Charges. -- Special terms for Government Officials and Officers of the Army of Occupation.
Telegraphic Address: BEAURIVAGE, Ramleh. – Telephone: 186, Ramleh. G. & M. RUNCKEWITZ, Proprietor.

div.head: Tewfik Palace Hotel.
div.p: Helouan, near Cairo.

Ideal English winter home. Moderate terms. Healthy situation. Lovely Gardens. Electric Light throughout. Perfect Sanitation. Pension Terms for Dec. and Jan. per day : Board- residence, Ss. 6d. ground floor( 10s, 6d including electric light and morning baths). 10s 6d. other floors(12s 6d including electric, morning bath, afternoon tes.) Double rooms allowed 5% discount. For fed., March, April, 2s and 4s. extra according to room.
For particulars. Apply Manager or Stephenson & Co., Opera Square, Cairo

Passengers can embark on Monday evening in the Brindisi steamer, which is timed to leave Port Said on Tuesday morning immediately after arrival of the homeward Indian Mail.
The Marseilles London Steamers sail after the arrival of the 11 a.m train from Cairo on Tuesdays.
25 per Cent. Abatement off Homeward Sea Fare to passengers making return Journey within 12 months.
Particulars of additional departures by Intermediate Steamers at reduced fares, to Malta, Calcutta, Straits, China, Japan, and London, may be had on application.

div.head: Local and General
div.p: The first small dance of the season at the Semiramis Hotel, Cairo, will be held to-morrow evening, commencing at 10 p.m.
Mr. Paul Garofallo has arrived at Suez, aid ' taken over his post, as Post-Master, succeeding Mr. Harrington who has been transferred to Port Said.
We have received from the. Austrian Lloyd Company, Trieste, a most attractively and artistically designed almanac for the year 1908.
The Egyptian Mail Steamship Company has ats arrangements for booking in advance passengers’ baggage from London to Alexan- dria and Cairo.

The Al Hayat orchestra, composed of fifteen . first class musicians, has arrived at Helovan ‘and will play on the terrace of the Sanatorium from 3.30 to 6 p.m. every Sunday, Monday, Wednesday, and Friday.

Two more patients suffering from plague have been admitted to hospital during ‘the «last 24 hours, and the number under treat- ment is at present 19. 1229 cases have been under treatment throughout Egypt from the ist January to the 16th December, and 892 of these have proved fatal.

Schuler’s Library, at Alexandria, has receiv- ed a consignment of an interesting English work on architecture, entitled “Flats, Urban. Houses, and Cottage Homes,” (Hodder and Stoughton, publishers ; London) This volume is beautifully illustrated-and would be of use to architects in this country for its very complete plans of the latest internal arrangements of London and Parisian flats.

A rew motor-car has been completed for Sir Francis Wingate, Sirdar of Egypt, by the New Arrol- Johnston Company. The engine, of 45 hp. nominally, but capable of higher power, is cased in sheet metal to be sandproof. The wheels are of cast steel, with discs of shee steel bolted on. to each side, and are fitted with ‘solid tyres. Paddle blades are bolted to the driving wheels for assistance in driving through soft. sand. The rubber tyres have narrower threads than usual to permit of sinking 1 in the ‘sand, as the wide, flat tyres first used in sand tended to churn up & bank in front, but the new tyre ainks to the hard, This is the. second car built, by the New Arrol-Johnston Company ~ for the Sirdar.

The fancy sale and ‘Christinas tree of the Sailors and Soldiers; [natitute will be held at the Institade next Friday, commencing at 3 p.m, Entrance tothe Sale will be P.T. 3 and to the Christmas tree, which will include 360 prizes, P.T. 5, T he following ladies have kindly consented to take stalls; —Miss Hilda Lang Anderson, Mrs. Neville Borton, Miss Garnett Botfield, Miss: Gertrude Carver, Miss Beatrice Davis, Miss Mafy Davis, Mrs Stanley Gordon, PhéHonble Mrs Hopkinson, Mrs. P.H. King- ham, Mrs.' Morrison, Mrs, Hicks Paull, Mrs, “Banwell: Rees, Mrs, Algernon Ward, and others. By kind permission of C olonel R.C.C. Cox and Officers, the String Band of the 2nd Batt. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers will play during the afternoon.

The excessive and continuons rise in honse rent in Alexandria and Cairo, in the face of an acute financial crisis, is one of the economic mysteries of Egypt. The same sort of thing has of late been going on at Naples - where the inhabitants have adopted a drastic method of solving the difficulty. Naples is.in the throes of something very closely resembling civil war owing to the rise of house-rent, which has been artificially pnt up by a syndicate of builders. Nearly 6,000 people have refused not only to pay their rent, but even to leave their houses, and the number of these passive resisters is so large that it is. impossible to dislodge them. Now the authorities have decided to evict them by force. The garrison has been reinforced hy 500 soldiers, 1,000 carabiniers, and 250 police men, to meet all possible emergencits.

Towards nine p m. on Friday week the German Levarit Line’s S.S. “Milos,” of Hamburg, was signalled in distress and on fire five miles westward of Ushant Light. The Maritime Pre- fecture immediately ordered Torpedo-boat 170 to proceed to the assistance of the “Milos,” and three steamers and several fishing-boats also went to help her. Eight men belonging to the crew were still on board, but twelve others had taken to a boat, and nothing has since been seen of them. On the following day, north of Moléme, the Hull steamer “Douro” tovk the “Milos” in tow, with the object of bringing her to Brest; but after encountering serious difficulties was compelled to relinquish the attempt, the tow rope having been burned. It is feared that the “Milos,” before she can be towed into safety, will run upon the rocks and become a total wreck. Lifeboats have gone in search of the twelve missing sailors, but it is feared that they have perished.

div.head: EGYPT AND ERYTHREA
div.p: AN INTERESTING COMPARISON.
LORD CROMER'S POLICY.

London, Tuesday. The former Roman Deputy. Signor Ostini, in the last number of the “Rivista Coloniale,” makes an. interesting comparison between England in Egypt and Italy in Erythrea. He holds up Lord Cromer’s administration to the admiration of his own countrymen, stating that Lord Cromer’s foremost aim was to gain the confidences of the native population, and he eulogised his great public works in the protection of the small native proprietor against the foreign capitalist, and his financial policy. He further remarks that in less than a quarter of a century Egypt has passed from bank- ruptcy to a state of prosperity such as no other purely agricultural country of the old world has attained. He proceeds to point oat to public opinion that Italy still regards the Red Sea colony with suspicion, due to the errors and disasters of the past. Yet, under the | ministration of the late Governor Martini, Erythrea had made considerable progress, and would have made more if they had‘been backed up at home
REX v. CANNON.

The last case to be heard at the Alexandria sessions of the Supreme Consular Court came on for hearing this morning. It is of interest as it is the first case of the trial of an English- man for the murder of another Englishman that has come before the Cons" larCoart within. living memory. Mr. Whitworth was counsel. for the accused, Thomas Cannon, who has been in Hadra Prison since the 24th October, when he was arrested by Mr. Blattner, the Superintendent of the Port City Police at Alexandria. The prosecution was conducted by Mr. Preston, the Crown Prosecutor for Egypt.

The crime was committed on board a petroleum steamer, the ‘Baku Standard” at Alexandria at about 1 a.m. on the 24th October last. Cannon cut the throat of a fellow fireman, named Henry King, who on his return to England was to have married. The Captain and several officers of the S.S. “Baku Standard” arrived on the 10th inst. from England by the S.S. “Heliopolis” in order to attend the trial. Several fireman belonging to the same steamer have been detained at the Sailors’ Home at Alexandria since the crime in order to give evidence before the Court.

Miss Janet Lewis has returned for her se: cond winter in Cairo, and is already exhibit- ing a few of her charming sketches in the salon of M. Zola, the well-known photographer, in Sharia Manakh. Miss Lewis has had the. advantage of a thorough training in art, for after her early education at South Kensington she spent three years of real hard work in Paris, where she studied under Jean Paul Laurem the late Benjamin Constant and other well known masters. Shé has studied in Holland, and has done good work in the best studies, and has exhibited in the Paris salon. Her sketches are but few in number, but they show real signs of c'everness and originality. They ate spontaneous in expression and good in colouring, and Miss Lewis has a very happy faculty for reproducing those clean, soft effects which cast so much aglamour over Egyptian scenes. Very noticeable in this respect is the sketch of the sheikh’s Tomb at Old Cairo, altogether an admirable bit of work, and the clean fresh treatment of the river bank of Ghizeh is also well worth mention.: The series entitled “The Wayside Restaurant,” “Pickle | shop,” and “Drapers shop” showmore ambitious composition, but they are very ,happily con- ceived and are executed with nite judgment of detail and colour. The most important of these sketches on show is that ofa street in Old Cairo, somewhat sombre m tone, but very able in its treatment. Miss Lewis is collecting material for a small exhibition in Piccadilly next spring, but prices are attached to her sketches now on view which should do much to make them popular. Miss Lewis is also a miniature painter of considerable suoces and is prepared to undertake portraits from photographs or personal sittings while she is in Cairo

Messrs. Lake and Currie, the company’s engineers, report as follows ;— Development— The “D" level south has advanced 5 ft., making a total distance of 103 ft. from the main shaft vrosseut. Driving in this level was stopped on 3rd October. Wince C.8. 2 has been started at a distance of 45 ft. north from No, 1 shaft, and at the end of the month had been sank to a depth of 20 ft. below ‘'C” level. The reef carries an average value of 4.1 dwts per ton over an average width of 40.5 ins (The portion of this winze sunk during the present month shows an improvement in both the value and width of the reef.) Stoping—The ore stoped during - month amounted to 710.9 .tons,° this being obtained from the C and D blocks. Mil ling—During ethe month the 10- -stampt mill treated 1,100 tons of ore, which yielded 299,446 ozs fine gold, exclusive of 2 tons of concontrates, having an assay value of 28 dwts per ton,
